title: A CUTandRUN protocol to determine patterns of epigenetic marks in imaginal discs of Drosophila
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Note: The first 100 steps of this protocol outline the procedure for the purification of the Protein A/G-MNase from bacteria. If a commercially sourced MNase enzyme is the be used, then these steps can be skipped. The actual CUT&RUN protocol begins on step 101.
Purification of MNase: Prepare reagents
Timing: 1 h
Preparation of reagents needed for the transformation of JM101 competent cells with the pA/G-MNase plasmid.
Dilute the pAG/MNase mini-prep to 1 ng/μL.
Turn on a 42°C water bath and give sufficient time to reach temperature.
Turn on a 37°C shaker and give sufficient time to reach temperature.
Thaw 100 μL of JM101 competent cells, keep on ice.
Purification of MNase: Transformation
Timing: 2 h with 16 h incubation
Transformation of JM101 competent E. coli cells with pAG/MNase plasmid from Addgene to prepare for bacterial production of the Protein A/G-MNase protein.
Add 1.7 μL of 10% 2-mercaptoethanol solution to 100 μL of thawed JM101 competent cells.
Mix by gently tapping the tube.
Incubate the cells on ice for 10 min, mix by gently tapping the tube every 2 min.
Add 1 μL of the 1 ng/μL pAG/MNase mini-prep dilution to the JM101 cells.
Mix by gently tapping the tube.
Incubate the cells on ice for 30 min.
Heat-shock the cells by incubating the tube in the 42°C water bath for 45 s.
Return the tube to ice, incubate on ice for 2 min.
Add 900 μL of SOC medium to the cells.
Place the tube in the 37°C shaker for 1 h with 250 rpm shaking.
Pipette 200 μL of the transformed cell mixture onto a LB+kanamycin plate and spread cells.
Incubate the plate at 37°C for 16 h.
Purification of MNase: Prepare reagents
Timing: 1 h

Preparation of regents needed for the large bacterial culture.
Prepare and autoclave 250 mL of LB medium in a 1 L flask, allow to cool to room temperature.
Purification of MNase: Inoculating the bacterial starter culture
Timing: 2 h with 16 h incubation
Preparing a bacterial starter culture from a colony on the transformation plate.
Remove the transformation plate from the incubator.
Pipette 5 mL of LB into a test tube.
Pipette 5 μL of kanamycin (50 mg/mL) to the LB in the test tube.
Pick a single bacterial colony from the transformation plate, transfer to the test tube with the LB.
Incubate the test tube at 37°C with 250 rpm shaking for 16 h.
Purification of MNase: Inoculating the large bacterial culture
Timing: 5 h
Using the bacterial starter culture to seed a large-scale culture.
Pipette 250 μL of kanamycin (50 mg/mL) into the 250 mL of LB in the flask that cooled overnight.
Pipette the entire 5 mL overnight culture of transformed bacteria into the flask.
Place the flask in a shaker and incubate at 37°C with 200 rpm shaking until the OD600 of the culture reaches 0.5–0.6 (approximately 4 h).
Remove the flask from the shaker. Cool the shaker to room temperature.
Purification of MNase: Induction of protein A/G-MNase production
Timing: 10 min with 16 h incubation
Turning on bacterial protein production of the Protein A/G-MNase by addition of IPTG.
Add 1.25 mL of 100 mM IPTG to the flask (0.5 mM final concentration) to induce bacterial protein production.
Place the flask in the shaker and incubate at 25°C with 200 rpm shaking for 16 h.
Purification of MNase: Collection of bacterial pellet
Timing: 2 h, 20 min
Collecting bacterial pellet and determining total weight of bacteria.

Weigh the empty bottle that will be used to centrifuge the 250 mL bacterial culture and note weight.
Transfer the 250 mL bacterial culture into the centrifuge bottle and centrifuge at room temperature for 15 min at 4,000 × g.
Decant the supernatant from the bacterial pellet.
Centrifuge the bottle again at room temperature for 1 min at 4,000 × g to collect all liquid at the bottom of the bottle.
Using a serological pipette, remove as much liquid as possible from the bacterial pellet.
Weigh the bottle again and note the weight of the bacterial pellet.
Freeze the bacterial pellet at −20°C for 2 h.
Purification of MNase: Extraction of total protein from bacteria
Timing: 45 min
Extracting total protein from bacterial pellet using B-PER lysing reagent.
Calculate the total weight of the bacterial pellet in grams.
Multiply this number by 5 to determine the amount of B-PER Complete Bacterial Protein Extraction Reagent you will need (in milliliters) to fully lyse the bacteria.
Pipette the calculated amount of B-PER into a 15 mL conical tube and add the required amount of 50× Protease Inhibitor Stock Solution to the B-PER. Mix by serological pipette.
Transfer the B-PER solution to the frozen bacterial pellet. Incubate the bottle containing the bacterial pellet and B-PER solution on ice until the pellet has thawed.
Gently pipette the B-PER solution in the bottle until the bacterial pellet is completely resuspended.
Transfer the resuspended bacterial pellet back into the 15 mL conical tube.
Incubate the tube at room temperature for 15 min with gentle rocking.
Centrifuge the 15 mL conical tube at 16,000 × g at room temperature for 20 min to separate the soluble from insoluble proteins.

Transfer the supernatant containing the soluble proteins (including the Protein A/G-MNase) to a clean 15 mL conical tube and store on ice.
Purification of MNase: Purification of the 6×HIS-tagged protein A/G-MNase
Timing: 1 h, 30 min
Using a nickel column to bind and purify the 6×HIS-tagged Protein A/G-MNase from the total soluble bacterial proteins.
Prepare the following solutions:
Equilibration Buffer (Ni-NTA column).
Wash Buffer (Ni-NTA column).
Elution Buffer (Ni-NTA column).
Remove a Ni-NTA column from the refrigerator and allow to warm to room temperature.
Shake the column to thoroughly resuspend the bead slurry.
Snap the end off from the column and place the column in a 15 mL conical tube. Loosen the cap on the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 700 × g at room temperature for 2 min to remove the storage buffer.
Discard the flow-through from the 15 mL conical tube, place column back into conical tube.
Add 2 mL of Equilibration Buffer to the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 700 × g at room temperature for 2 min to remove the Equilibration Buffer.
Discard the flow-through from the 15 mL conical tube.
Place the white rubber cap on the end of the column to prevent loss of liquid.
Pipette up to 7 mL of the protein extraction solution into the column.
Incubate the column at room temperature for 30 min with gentle rocking.
Remove the white rubber cap and place the column back into the 15 mL conical tube. Loosen the cap on the column.
Allow the solution to drip through the column by gravity, emptying the 15 mL conical tube when necessary to prevent the flow-through from touching the tip of the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 700 × g at room temperature for 2 min to remove any residual protein extraction solution.

Discard the flow-through from the 15 mL conical tube, place column back into the conical tube.
Pipette 2 mL of Wash Buffer into the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 700 × g at room temperature for 2 min to remove the Wash Buffer.
Discard the flow-through from the 15 mL conical tube.
Repeat the above wash step 3 additional times.
After the final wash step, place the column into a clean 15 mL conical tube.
Add 1 mL of Elution Buffer to the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 700 × g at room temperature for 2 min to collect the Elution Buffer and eluted Protein A/G-MNase.
Add an additional 1 mL of Elution Buffer to the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 700 × g at room temperature for 2 min to collect the Elution Buffer and eluted Protein A/G-MNase. There is no need to collect the two elutions as separate fractions, they should be mixed.
Discard the column and store the eluted purified Protein A/G-MNase on ice.
Purification of MNase: Removal of imidazole from purified protein A/G-Mnase
Timing: 20 min
Zeba Spin Desalting Column used to remove excess imidazole from the purified Protein A/G-MNase.
Snap the tab off the bottom of a 10 mL Zeba Spin Desalting Column.
Place the column in a 50 mL conical tube and loosen the cap.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 1,000 × g at room temperature for 2 min to remove the storage buffer.
Discard the flow-through from the conical tube.
Pipette 5 mL of PBS into the column to equilibrate.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 1,000 × g at room temperature for 2 min to remove the PBS.
Discard the flow-through from the conical tube.
Repeat the PBS equilibration spins 3 additional times.

Place the column into a new 50 mL conical tube.
Slowly pipette the 2 mL purified Protein A/G-MNase sample directly onto the resin of the column.
Centrifuge the column/conical tube at 1,000 × g at room temperature for 2 min to elute the desalted purified Protein A/G-MNase from the column.
Pipette the desalted purified Protein A/G-MNase solution into a new 15 mL conical tube, store on ice.
Purification of MNase: Prepare protein standards for Bradford Assay
Timing: 10 min
BSA used to make a series of protein standards for use in a Bradford Assay.
Prepare 6 BSA protein standard solutions using a fresh ampule of 2.0 mg/mL BSA Protein and PBS as follows:
Tube A: 100 μL PBS.
Tube B: 100 μL BSA (no dilution).
Tube C: 100 μL BSA + 100 μL PBS.
Tube D: 100 μL of Tube C + 100 μL PBS.
Tube E: 100 μL of Tube D + 100 μL PBS.
Tube F: 100 μL of Tube E + 100 μL PBS.
Purification of MNase: Bradford Assay to determine protein concentration
Timing: 30 min
NanoDrop One Spectrophotometer used to determine the concentration of Protein A/G-MNase in sample.
Invert the bottle of Coomassie Plus (Bradford) Assay Reagent several time to mix.
Pipette 250 μL of Coomassie Plus (Bradford) Assay Reagent into each of six tubes labelled Tube A∗-Tube F∗.
Pipette 5 μL of each BSA protein standard prepared above into its corresponding tube of Coomassie Reagent.
Pulse vortex each tube several times to mix.
Incubate the tubes at room temperature for 10 min.
While the samples incubate, prepare the NanoDrop One Spectrophotometer for a Bradford Assay.
From the Home Screen, choose the Proteins tab.
Select Protein Bradford.
Set the Curve Type to 2nd Order Polynomial.
Set replicates to 3.
Enter your standards into the chart.

Tube A: 0 mg/mL.
Tube B: 2,000 mg/mL.
Tube C: 1,000 mg/mL.
Tube D: 500 mg/mL.
Tube E: 250 mg/mL.
Tube F: 125 mg/mL.
Pipette 4 μL of Tube A (plain PBS) on the pedestal as a blank.
Measure 4 μL of each sample, as prompted by the spectrophotometer, to prepare the standard curve.
Prepare your experimental sample by pipetting 5 μL of the desalted purified Protein A/G-MNase sample into 250 μL of Coomassie Plus (Bradford) Assay Reagent.
Pulse vortex several times to mix.
Incubate the tube at room temperature for 10 min.
Pipette 4 μL of the sample solution onto the pedestal to determine the concentration of desalted purified Protein A/G-MNase.
Purification of MNase: Preparation of protein A/G-MNase solution for long-term storage
Timing: 10 min
Dilution of Protein A/G-MNase solution with glycerol.
Pipette 2 mL of sterile 80% glycerol to the 2 mL desalted purified Protein A/G-Mnase sample.
Gently pipette up and down several times to mix.
Pipette the protein solution into 200 μL aliquots.
Print labels for the tubes with the date of purification and concentration, remembering that the protein concentration is now half of what was determined using the Bradford Assay.
Freeze tubes at −20°C for long-term storage.
CUT&RUN: Prepare reagents
Timing: 15 min
Preparation of the all the solutions and reagents needed for the first part of the CUT&RUN protocol. Use the primary solutions prepared prior to starting the protocol.
Prepare Wash+ Buffer from pre-made Wash Buffer. Store on ice.
Prepare Dig-Wash+ Buffer using freshly made Wash+ Buffer. Store on ice.
Prepare Antibody Buffer using freshly made Dig-Wash+ Buffer. Store on ice.
Prepare the Concanavalin A beads for tissue binding. All steps are at room temperature.
Thoroughly mix the Concanavalin A bead slurry by gently inverting the bottle several times.

Pipette 15 μL of Concanavalin A bead slurry into each of two LoBind tubes (one tube for the experimental sample, one tube for a negative control).
Resuspend the beads in 1 mL of Binding Buffer.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow beads to migrate to magnet.
Remove the supernatant.
Repeat the Binding Buffer wash step once more, remove supernatant.
Centrifuge the tubes briefly, return to magnetic rack. Remove all supernatant.
Resuspend the beads in 1 mL of Wash+ Buffer.
Store on ice.
CUT&RUN: Dissection of imaginal discs and binding of tissue to concanavalin A beads
Timing: 30 min
Preparation and collection of imaginal disc samples and binding to magnetic beads (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2513-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Dissection of imaginal discs and final product
(A) A diagram of the initial dissection product. It usually contains the mouth hooks, salivary glands, fat body, eye-antennal discs and brain complex. Green and red asterisks indicate areas that, when removed, will lead to the clean detachment of the eye-antennal disc.
(B) A light microscope image of a fully dissected eye-antennal disc. The tissue has been treated with phalloidin which attaches to F-actin. This reveals the overall morphology of the disc. Please see the written and video protocol in Spratford and Kumar, 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13] for a more detailed description of the dissection procedure.
Note: Please see the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section, problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.1] and problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.3] for help resolving certain issues related to this step of the protocol.
Place the two LoBind tubes containing the Concanavalin A beads in Wash+ Buffer on ice.
Depending upon the abundance of the chromatin mark being investigated, place 10–30 wandering 3rd instar larvae into a small petri dish containing sterile water and allow larvae to swim around for a few minutes to free the larval cuticle of excess food.

Note: Each larva contains two eye-antennal imaginal discs. If you are recovering other imaginal discs note that within a larva there are two labial discs, two clypeolabral discs, two wing discs, two haltere discs, six leg discs, and one genital disc.
Transfer each clean larva to a small pool (∼1 mL) of Wash+ Buffer at the edge of a silicone-based dissection plate.
Using forceps transfer a single larva to a large pool (∼2 mL) of Wash+ Buffer in the middle of the same silicone-based dissection plate.
Using two pair of forceps, one in each hand, grasp and lightly hold the larva lengthwise with forceps.
Note: One pair of forceps should be used to gently but stably hold the larva approximately 1/3 of the body length from the mouth hooks. The other pair of forceps should be used to grab onto the mouth hooks.
Holding the mouth hooks steady, quickly but gently pull the body of the larva away from the mouth hooks. You should feel a slight release in tension as the larva tears apart.
Release the forceps holding the body of the larva and allow for the internal tissues remaining attached to the mouth hooks to spread out.
Immediately transfer the larval carcass (the portion without the mouth hooks, brain hemispheres, ventral ganglion, salivary glands and imaginal discs) out of the dissection bubble.
Holding the mouth hook complex firmly use a pair of forceps to remove the excess tissues including the salivary glands and overlying cuticle until a single complex of mouth hooks, brain hemispheres, ventral ganglion and imaginal discs remain.
Orient the remaining complex with the ventral side facing downwards.

Use one pair of forceps to again firmly hold the mouth hooks. With a second pair of forceps, remove the brain hemispheres by placing a single tong into the space between the brain and eye-antennal discs and rapidly pulling the brain away from the mouth hooks.
Note: For a visual demonstration of the dissection of imaginal discs please see the video protocol associated with Spratford and Kumar, 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13].
Isolate the remaining imaginal tissues by pinching off the discs as closely as possible to the connecting cuticle.
Once the imaginal discs are free from all other tissue transfer the newly dissected disc to the LoBind tube containing the Concanavalin A beads in Wash+ Buffer.
For abundant chromatin marks such as trimethylation of lysine 27 on histone H3 (H3K27me3) repeat above steps until 10 individual imaginal discs have been transferred to each of the two LoBind tubes. For less abundant chromatin marks such as trimethylation of lysine 4 on histone H3 (H3K4me3) repeat the above steps until 30 individual imaginal discs have been transferred to each of two LoBind tubes.
Incubate the tubes at room temperature with inversion for 10 min to allow the beads to bind to the tissue.
CUT&RUN: Primary antibody incubation
Timing: 10 min with 16 h incubation
Digitonin perforates tissue, allowing primary antibody to bind targets in the nucleus.
Note: Please see the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section, problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.5] and problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.7] for help resolving certain issues related to this step of the protocol.
Note: The molecular portion this CUT&RUN protocol is adapted from the protocol developed by Kami Ahmad: https://www.protocols.io/view/cut-run-with-drosophila-tissues-umfeu3n[href=https://www.protocols.io/view/cut-run-with-drosophila-tissues-umfeu3n] and the EpiCypher CUT&RUN protocol: https://www.epicypher.com/resources/protocols/cutana-cut-and-run-protocol/[href=https://www.epicypher.com/resources/protocols/cutana-cut-and-run-protocol/].

Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow the bead-bound tissue to migrate to magnet for approximately 2 min. Collected tissue that has migrated to the magnet is clearly visible on the inside of the tube.
Remove all supernatant.
Briefly centrifuge the tubes in a benchtop mini-centrifuge to collect the tissue at the bottom of the tube, return tubes to the magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all residual supernatant.
Add 100 μL of Antibody Buffer to the tissue pellet in each tube.
Add 2 μL of the primary antibody (100 μg/mL) (either Cell Signaling Technology Tri-Methyl-Histone H3 (Lys27) (C36B11) Rabbit antibody or Sigma-Aldrich Trimethyl-Histone H3 (Lys4), Clone 15-10C-E4, Rabbit Monoclonal) to one tube. Final working concentration of the primary antibody is approximately 2 ng/μL.
Add 2 μL of the Cell Signaling Normal Rabbit IgG control antibody (1 mg/mL) to the second tube. Final working concentration of the control antibody is 20 ng/μL.
Mix the solution and resuspend the tissue pellets by gentle pipetting.
Incubate overnight for 16 h at 4°C with gentle shaking.
CUT&RUN: Prepare reagents
Timing: 1 h
Preparation of the all the solutions and equipment needed for the second part of the CUT&RUN protocol.
Prepare STOP-R Buffer from pre-made STOP Buffer.
Heat Eppendorf ThermoMixer F1.5 with ThermoTop Lid to 37°C.
Cool a refrigerated table-top centrifuge to 4°C.
CUT&RUN: Primary antibody wash
Timing: 10 min
Excess unbound antibody washed from the tissue.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all supernatant.
Pipette 1 mL of Dig-Wash+ Buffer into each tube, invert several times to resuspend tissue.
Incubate at room temperature for 1 min.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all supernatant.

Pipette 1 mL of Dig-Wash+ Buffer into each tube, invert several times to resuspend tissue.
Incubate at room temperature for 1 min.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all supernatant.
Briefly centrifuge the tubes in a benchtop mini-centrifuge to collect the tissue at the bottom of the tubes, return tubes to the magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all residual supernatant.
CUT&RUN: Nuclease tethering
Timing: 1 h, 5 min
Protein A/G-MNase binds to primary antibody.
Note: Please see the troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] section, problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec7.9] for help resolving certain issues related to this step of the protocol.
Note: The concentration of the Protein A/G-MNase stock solution that was made in our lab is 800 ng/μL. We have found this starting concentration to be sufficient for providing robust and reliable chromatin cleavage following dilution.
Note: Our Protein A/G MNase stock was made in-lab by first transforming bacterial cells with the pAG/MNase plasmid (#123461) available from AddGene. This was followed by induction of protein production, protein extraction and column purification, and finally desalting of the purified protein. Concentration of the purified protein was determined by a Bradford assay. A full description for producing the Protein A/G-MNase from the AddGene plasmid can be found at the beginning of this protocol.
Prepare a fresh dilution of Protein A/G-MNase by pipetting 1 μL of the Protein A/G-MNase stock (800 ng/μL) into 1 mL of Dig-Wash+ Buffer. Mix by gentle vortexing.
Pipette 150 μL of the Protein A/G-Mnase dilution into each tube.
Resuspend the tissue pellets by gentle pipetting.
Incubate the tubes at 4°C for 1 h with gentle shaking.
CUT&RUN: Nuclease wash
Timing: 10 min
Excess unbound Protein A/G-Mnase washed from tissue.

Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all supernatant.
Pipette 1 mL of Dig-Wash+ Buffer into each tube, invert several times to resuspend tissue.
Incubate at room temperature for 1 min.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all supernatant.
Pipette 1 mL of Dig-Wash+ Buffer into each tube, invert several times to resuspend tissue.
Incubate at room temperature for 1 min.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all supernatant.
Briefly centrifuge the tubes in a benchtop mini-centrifuge to collect the tissue at the bottom of the tubes, return tubes to the magnetic rack and allow tissue to migrate to magnet.
Remove all residual supernatant.
CUT&RUN: Chromatin cleavage and release
Timing: 2 h, 45 min
Protein A/G-Mnase nuclease activity activated by addition of calcium, cleaved chromatin released from tissue.
Resuspend the tissue pellets in 150 μL of Dig-Wash+ Buffer and place the tubes on ice for 5 min to chill.
Add 3 μL of 100 mM CaCl2 (2 mM final concentration) to each tube and mix by gentle pipetting.
Immediately return the tubes to ice.
Incubated tubes on ice for 2 h.
Add 100 μL of STOP-R Buffer to each tube and mix by gentle pipetting.
Incubate the tubes in an Eppendorf ThermoMixer F1.5 at 37°C for 30 min with 500 rpm shaking to help cleaved DNA fragments exit the tissue.
CUT&RUN: Cleaved chromatin purification
Timing: 30 min
Cleaved chromatin fragments purified using the Qiagen MinElute PCR Purification Kit.
Using the refrigerated table-top centrifuge, centrifuge the tubes at 16,000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Place the tubes in a magnetic rack and allow the tissue to migrate to the magnet.

Transfer the supernatant from each tube, which now contains the cleaved chromatin, to two new LoBind tubes.
Pipette 1.25 mL of Buffer PB into each of the tubes.
Ensure that the color of the solution is yellow (correct pH).
For each sample, place a Qiagen MinElute spin column in a collection tube.
Transfer 800 μL of the chromatin solution to a Qiagen MinElute spin column.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 1 min at room temperature.
Discard the flow-through from the collection tube, and reinsert the column.
Transfer the remainder of the DNA solution into the Qiagen MinElute spin column.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 1 min at room temperature.
Discard the flow-through from the collection tube, and reinsert the column.
Pipette 750 μL of Buffer PE into the column to wash.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 1 min at room temperature.
Discard the flow-through from the collection tube, and reinsert the column.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 1 min at room temperature to dry the column.
Discard the collection tube and insert each of the columns into two new LoBind tubes.
Pipette 10 μL of Buffer EB directly onto the center of each MinElute column membrane.
Incubate the columns for 2 min at room temperature.
Centrifuge at 18,000 × g for 1 min at room temperature.
Discard the columns and store the eluted, purified chromatin fragments at −20°C.
CUT&RUN: Library production and NGS
Samples are submitted to the IU Center for Genomics and Bioinformatics, our in-house Genome Services Facility, for DNA library production and next-generation sequencing from the isolated chromatin fragments.

In our experience with over 100 samples, performing CUT&RUN using histone marks with broad domains yields purified chromatin fragments with concentrations of 200–300 pg/μL as measured by an Invitrogen Qubit 3 Fluorometer using the dsDNA high-sensitivity assay. For more narrow histone marks the concentration of purified chromatin fragments is not detectable by NanoDrop spectrophotometer, Qubit fluorometer, or Agilent TapeStation. However, even with undetectable concentrations, we have never encountered a sample that was unable to produce a quality DNA library.
DNA libraries are prepared using the NEBNext Ultra II DNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina from New England Biolabs. The DNA fragments obtained from the CUT&RUN protocol described here are used as-is for DNA library production. No further shearing or fragmentation is necessary.
Next-generation sequencing is carried out using Illumina NextSeq equipment at a read-depth of 15 M reads per sample.
